coredata.dc:title: ILP turns 20: Biography and future challenges

abstract.ce:para: Inductive Logic Programming (ILP) is an area of Machine Learning which has now reached its twentieth year. Using the analogy of a human biography this paper recalls the development of the subject from its infancy through childhood and teenage years. We show how in each phase ILP has been characterised by an attempt to extend theory and implementations in tandem with the development of novel and challenging real-world applications. Lastly, by projection we suggest directions for research which will help the subject coming of age. Â© 2011 The Author(s).

affiliation.affilname: Research Organization of Information and Systems National Institute of Informatics

xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency: Centre on Innovation and Energy Demand, University of Sussex

xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency-matched-string: Centre for Integrative Systems Biology at Imperial College
Royal Academy of Engineering and Microsoft Research

xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency: Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: Acknowledgements SHM would like to thank the Royal Academy of Engineering and Microsoft Research for their support of his research chair. SM also acknowledges the support of Syngenta Ltd in the University Innovation Centre at Imperial College and the BBSRC for their funding of the Centre for Integrative Systems Biology at Imperial College. AS is a Ramanujan Fellow of the Government of India; and for some period of this work was at the School of Computational and Integrative Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi. AS is also a Visiting Professor at the Computing Laboratory, University of Oxford; and an Adjunct Professor at the School of CSE, University of New South Wales, Sydney.

item-info.copyright: Copyright 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

citation-title.titletext: ILP turns 20: Biography and future challenges

abstract.ce:para: Inductive Logic Programming (ILP) is an area of Machine Learning which has now reached its twentieth year. Using the analogy of a human biography this paper recalls the development of the subject from its infancy through childhood and teenage years. We show how in each phase ILP has been characterised by an attempt to extend theory and implementations in tandem with the development of novel and challenging real-world applications. Lastly, by projection we suggest directions for research which will help the subject coming of age. Â© 2011 The Author(s).
